qas.question: How are staples of classical music often used?
TV commercials using Richard Strauss' Also sprach Zarathustra have now become what?
What piece is often used in the horror genre?

answers.text: "O Fortuna" of Carl Orff's Carmina Burana

qas.question: Who wrote Ride of the Valkyries?
Who wrote in the Hall of the Mountain King?

context: Certain staples of classical music are often used <a0_0>commercially<a0_0/> (either in advertising or in movie soundtracks). In television commercials, several passages have become <a1_0>clichéd<a1_0/>, particularly the opening of Richard Strauss' Also sprach Zarathustra (made famous in the film 2001: A Space Odyssey) and the opening section <a2_0>"O Fortuna" of Carl Orff's Carmina Burana<a2_0/>, often used in the horror genre; other examples include the Dies Irae from the Verdi Requiem, <a4_0>Edvard Grieg<a4_0/>'s In the Hall of the Mountain King from Peer Gynt, the opening bars of Beethoven's Symphony No. 5, <a3_0>Wagner<a3_0/>'s Ride of the Valkyries from Die Walküre, Rimsky-Korsakov's Flight of the Bumblebee, and excerpts of Aaron Copland's Rodeo.
